en: Once in the Robinson collection. Harvard Inv. no. 139.

On Side A, a warrior stands in the center of the composition, facing right. The warrior appears to wear a very strange square hemmed chiton, which extends below his round shield. He also wears a Corinthian helmet and greaves. The shield carries five white balls as a shield device. Two horsemen shown frontally flank the warrior. They wear white chitons and greaves. Robinson 1956 interprets these figures as the Dioskouroi. The painter may well have intended them as such, but this is not certain. The Dioskouroi acquire identifying attributes relatively late, thus precise identification in Archaic art can be difficult. Riders are very popular in Attic vase painting of the sixth century, and not all pairs of riders were meant to represent the Dioskouroi.

On Side B, A young woman stands at the left of the composition facing right. She wears a decorated peplos and himation, and has a fillet in her hair. A spear leans against her shoulder. She gestures with her left hand toward the departing figure at the right. A bearded man wearing a long chiton and himation stands in the center, facing right. He holds a spear or staff in his left hand. On the right, a youth moves to the right looking back over his shoulder. He wears a fillet in his hair, a short chiton, and a mantle. He also holds a spear.

The neck of the vase is decorated with addorsed palmettes. A running meander above a zone of rays decorates the lower body of the vase. The area under the handles is filled with a palmette and lotus bud motif.
